sage.scene.state.jogl

Class JOGLTextureState

  • java.lang.Object
    • sage.scene.state.RenderState
      • sage.scene.state.TextureState
        • sage.scene.state.jogl.JOGLTextureState

  • public class JOGLTextureState
extends TextureState
    JOGLTextureState provides a JOGL API implementation of the abstract class TextureState. It provides all the requirements of a TextureState object in a JOGL-specific way.

    Note: the current implementation does not support more than the basic texturing operations. In particular it doesn't support rescaling of non-power-of-two sized textures, MIPmapped textures, or any of the following texture modes: blending, environment mapping, combiner units, border colors, texture transforms, texture wrap modes, shadow textures, texture filtering, or automatic texture coordinate generation. All of these are planned for development in a future release.

    Author:
    John Clevenger, based on a similar class in JMonkeyEngine.

    • Constructor Detail

      • JOGLTextureState

        public JOGLTextureState(JOGLContextCapabilities caps)
        Constructs a new JOGLTextureState object describing a set of texture state values. The default values in the JOGLTextureState are determined by the properties of the JOGLContextCapabilities object passed to the constructor. In particular, the number of different textures supported by the JOGLTextureState is determined by the number of texture units supported by the graphics card as defined in the specified JOGLContextCapabilities.

    • Method Detail

      • load

        public final void load(int unit)
        Loads the specified texture unit on the graphics card with the Texture contained in this JOGLTextureState, if any Texture has been assigned in this JOGLTextureState to the specified unit.
        Specified by:
        load in class TextureState

      • apply

        public void apply()
        apply() applies the textures described by this JOGLTextureState to the underlying OpenGL system. If the texture has not been loaded yet, it is generated and loaded. This means the initial pass to set will be longer than subsequent calls. The multitexture extension is used to define the multiple texture states, with the number of units being determined at construction time.
        Specified by:
        apply in class TextureState
        See Also:
        RenderState.apply()

      • applyFilters

        public void applyFilters(Texture texture,
                         TextureRecord texRecord,
                         int unit,
                         TextureStateRecord record)
        Applies the texture magnification, minification, and anisotropic filters attached to the specified Texture object to the underlying OpenGL system.
        Parameters:
        texture - the texture object
        texRecord - the record of the last state of the particular texture in gl
        unit - the texture unit containing the specified texture
        record - the renderer's TextureStateRecord (for all textures in the texture state)
